name: Bennie G. Thompson
tweet_text: It was not decided until 1968 when the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Mississippi beaches were public and had to be desegregated by federal law.

name: Bennie G. Thompson
tweet_text: Mason filed the first school desegregation lawsuit in the history of Biloxi, which he also won.  A legal challenge to the segregation had been initiated by the U.S. Department of Justice in May 1960 but had been delayed in getting a court hearing.

name: Bennie G. Thompson
tweet_text: Mason led a third wade-in protest at the beach in spring 1963, two weeks after the funeral for Medgar Evers. The protesters faced a much larger group of nearly 2000 white protesters, but this time the police prevented violence against them.

name: Bennie G. Thompson
tweet_text: These resulted in a successful anti-discrimination lawsuit against the state of Mississippi, the first such case filed in U.S. history. They were attacked by groups of whites across the beaches as the Biloxi police stood by without taking action.

name: Bennie G. Thompson
tweet_text: He led a nonviolent protest against the ‚Äúwhites only‚Äù section of a federally funded Gulf Coast beach.  Mason‚Äôs group was arrested.  Subsequent ‚Äúwade-ins‚Äù ignited some of the bloodiest white riotings in Mississippi history.

name: Bennie G. Thompson
tweet_text: He is most notable for organizing and participating in Mississippi's first nonviolent civil disobedience action, known as the Biloxi wade-ins, which took place from 1959 to 1963.

name: Bennie G. Thompson
tweet_text: Dr. Gilbert R. Mason, Sr. was a physician who was known as the ‚Äúwade-in‚Äù activist.  Mason started a family practice in Biloxi, Mississippi, in 1955. https://t.co/cffu0OvjEa
